Title: Early Detection of Brain Metastases
Scoping: Screening: aim to detect at least a month before MRI
Needs Statement: Need a way to detect micro metastatic lesions in patients who underwent resection and/or radiotherapy so that we can employ early treatment and limit comorbidities
State of Art: MRI can detect only when lesions are greater than 1 cm
Solution: Positron Emission Tomography (PET); imaging molecules that will glow only when they hold on to cencer cells; key step: identify protiens that express on surface of cancer cells, design molecules that will bind to proteins of interest and the other half to glow compound;
Literature: 10.1093/noajnl/vdac033; 10.3390/cancers14174328;https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/common.html;  10.1227/01.neu.0000073546.61154.9a; 10.1186/s12967-016-1035-1; Preliminary study of New Gallium-68 Radiolabeled Peptide Targeting NRP-1 to detect

Title: Ezure
Observation: 3.4 M Americans have active epilepsy; 1 in 26 have recurrent siezures; patients don’t remember their seizure episodes; 15.5Bn spent in treating each year; Providers use a trial and error algorithm to figure out the best anti epileptic drug that can prevent recurrant siezures; sleep deprivation and medicine non compliance are factors that trigger recurrance of siezures
Needs Statement: Need a way to assess and track siezure risk factors in patients with diagnosed epilepsy in order to reduce siezure recurrance
State of Art: During Seizures:SeizAlarm, track it seizure log;snug safety; Pst Seizure: journaling simplified. Most of them require users to provide all the information to the app
Solution: Ezure: an app that can pull data from existing information such as sleep, lifestyle, heartrate, menstruation, nausea. App creates a prediction for seizures and suggest lifestyle changes. App requires patient input. App helps in monitoring memory as well.

Title: Parkinson's Disease Cueing
Observation: Medications are effective in treating motor symptoms, it is progressive so patient conditions deteriorate. There are episodes of freezing, akinesia; Affects 1% of Americans over 60; $52b; 10 million globally. Pa
Needs Statement: Need to improve treatment of Parkinson's disease in patients who experience akinesia as their medications fail to work to help them retain mobility
State of Art: Medications: Sinemet, Ropinirole, pramipexole. Therapy: physical, assistive devices, music
Solution: cueing: though frozen individuals may be able to move when dancing or cueing to a rhythm. Solution: PD rhythm app adjusts the tempo of their favourite music to help them with their gait. Also evaluates their gait. Compliance is a big issue with music therapy. How do we evaluate impact: walking speed, engagement, patient satisfaction.

Title: Determining Stroke Age by MRI
Keywords: Stroke, MR sequence, machine learning, image classification
Observation: Patient diagnosed with stroke; diagnosed with sizable ischemic stroke; last known normal 4 hrs ago; not a candidate for thrombolytic therapy; Alteplase could have helped if onset was known. After 4.5 hrs risk of hemorrhage increases. Some trials have used imaging.
Needs Statement: Need to accurately indentify the age of stroke in emergency patients in order to provide more effective treatment.
State of Art: Fast MR imaging sequence.
Solution: Machine learning tools on MRI and fast MR sequences. ML can capture subtle changes and determine stroke age.Formulating as a simple Image Classification problem. Incorporate in ED protocol. Needed: training dataset from EMRs

Title: Asynchronous Communication
Observation: Nursing staff not qualified on the risk for lumbar puncture; Patient anxious about LP; Patient's questions unanswered; Patients have no understanding of 2/3 of medication changes or new medications. Hospitalized patients had limited understanding of their diagnosis or treatment plans. Rounds are intense with an average of 5.5 min/round. Only 66% of the hospitals had secure messaging
Needs Statement: Need a way to address patient questions regarding risks and concerns of a process or medication in patients who are hospitalized in order to improve quality of care, patient communication and satisfaction.
State of Art: Pateints questions answered only on rounds.
Solution: Application for providers and patients to securely exchange messages; incorporate features of voalte; integrate nursing, social work etc. Other applications may not be secure enough. May require hardware: for patients and providers; message cap; some  messages may need to be filtered and answered by nurses; Limitations: work-life boundaries, more work for provider; access to smartphones

Title: CogHealth: An innovative approach to neuropsychological testing
Observation:
Difficult to schedule appointment with neuropsychologist due to comorbidities, age etc.
1/5 of urban communities lack access, 47% non metro lack access
Teleneurology is an option: 5 hrs time savings; $48k saved; very satisfied
Needs Statement: Need to provide seamless neuropsychological testing access to individuals irrespective of age, socioeconomic status, mental status, distance etc. for efficient treatment and diagnosis of neuropsychological diseases
State of Art: FSTAC ipad-based neuro psych testing, not FDA approved, not all providers use
Solution: Coghealth: online neuropsychological testing app with eye tracking algorithm to factor teaching and distraction, no need for proctor, guided practice, bioprofiling with tracking heart rate, mobile data

Title: Pressure-Activated protective Cap for High-Risk Fall Patients
Observation: Falls are secondary to seizures or stroke; Many patients do not remember events that led to fall or after the fall; 1/4 adults over 65 report falling every year; 36 millinon falls and 8 millinon injuries every year; over 200k TBI related hospitalization in 2019, and 60k deaths in 2020; 73% of post stroke patients fall in the next one year; Epileptics are several times likelier to fall
Needs Statement: A way to prevent serious traumatic brain injuries (TBI) in unwitnessed fall patients in order to decrease the rate of TBI-related hospitalizations and deaths
State of Art: puffed up protective headwear; hard shell protective baseball cap with a foam interior lining; necklace that those who are at the risk of falling can wear (user presses button to alert others); Most solutions require the patient or witness;
Solution: protective hard shell baseball cap and line it with thin pressure sensors; pressure on the sensors beyond a threshold can trigger an alert; Challenges: false alarm, way to clean the cap;

Title: Carpe Diem: Distinguishing Pseudo-seizures from Epilepsy
Observation: A patient experiencing seizures; experiencing body jerks; no loss of consciousness; EEG was normal but she experienced an event during hospital stay; diagnosed with psychogenic non elileptic seizures; Signs: forced eye closure, distractibility, protecting vital body parts, ictal stuttering; causes: stress, chronic medical conditions; 24-33% of EMU admissions; average; Seizure medication may be detrimental; cost 20k per patient
Needs Statement: We need a way to help home caretakers identify PNES in patients with epilepsy in order to decrease unnecessary hospital utilization
State of Art: Home EEG devices; Neurosky mindware; Emotiv Epoc; marketed as medication device; because interpreting requires medical professionals
Solution: Carpe Diem: motion capture system that can help caretakers characterize seizure-like episodes; it consists of a wearable motion capture device on wrist and head; smartphone app pairs with it; when activity detected, caretaker records an event in the app; app assesses patients movement for signs of psychogenic seizure; can be shared with providers

Title: The R-Eye-Flex Hammer
Observation: A study: Practitioners should standardize lighting conditions to maximize measurement reliability
Needs Statement: A way to make an easy-to-use (and easy to find!) pen light to examine patients with neurological compliants to make the findings from the exam more exact and improve the provider's experience with light
State of Art: Neurologist prefer to use their phone rather than their pen light because of short battery life; Pen light is sharp, while phone light is bright at the center and fades towards the edge;
Solution: A Rye-Flex Hammer; hammer has a pen light at the end and a vibration action; more reliable light; will be difficult to lose;

Title: HomeSafe
Observation: Home safety checks were conducted on a dimentia patient; Patient was working on making home safer for fall prevention; falls accounts for over $50 billion annual costs; 600k die due to falls worldwide;
Needs Statement: A way to assess and actionably safe-proof a home for aging older adults in order to improve home safety and reduce the number of in-home falls
State of Art: Home safety check is provided by an occupational therapist using a checklist; items are reviewed; and recommendations given; Medicare covers 65 and over;
Solution: Home Services for Assessment and Falls Evaluation (HomeSafe); patient will record themselves performing daily activities within the home, the video will be uploaded to a server and reviewed by professionals, personalized report generated; Every video frame will be annotated for potential fall risks; Advantages: personalized, visual. May help for those not qualified under medicare; Future: could be automated using machine learning.

Title: Smart Note: NLP to reduce patient and physician frustration and improve communication and EHR documentation
Keywords: Natural Language Programming, NLP, Electronic Health Record, HER, stroke
Observation: Stroke patients need to repeat their stories multiple times to both their initial providers and the specialists. This causes frustration. Poor communication between the initial providers and specialists were also observed. 795k/year strokes; EMR allows communication of large amounts of data but may reduce provider-provider face to face communication;
Needs Statement: A way to imporve accuracy and efficiency of patient-provider and provider-provider communication in patients, primary team providers and specialty providers in order to improve efficiency of patient care and reduce patient frustration in the care process
State of Art: Expanded need: work with existing system; HIPAA compliant; Consistency; Providing timely orders to right person; Access for all team members
Solution: Smart Note: AI intervention;AI mines patient's histroy from EMR; AI updates the notes with additional information as the patient shares notes; When patient and provider are speaking AI picks up key points and autopopulates others from history

Title: LazBed
Observation: Pateint recovering from stroke in inpatient rehab was trying to reach for phone from hospital bed; knocked over water; maneuvering bedside tables difficult; Historically hospital beds have been designed to prioritize the ability to provide care to the patient; not the patient's comfort; Patients feel restricted and isolated;Providers unable to get patients in and out; 75% found ADLs painful
Needs Statement: A way to improve the ergonomic design of hospital beds in order to improve the ease of ADLs for >50% bedbound patients.
State of Art: Adjustable bed segments
Solution: Design Framework: Compile a list of what is important for the patient in the order of importance: 1. Better access to personal belongings;2.  Easier to get in and out of bed; 3. Convenient way to access food and drink on demand; 3. Be able to access food and drink without body contortion; Others: reach and understand bed controls; A simple design of a table connected to bed.

Title: Aphasia Rapid Test Translator Tool (ART3)
Keywords: Aphasia; limited english proficiency (LEP); acquired neurogenic communication disorders (ACDs); speech to text
Observation: Patient who does not speak English; Required video interpreter; not able to assess patient's speech for neurogenic speech disorder;Aphasia: Approximately 23.6 million patients in US have limited English proficiency (LEP); LEPs have lower quality of life after stroke due to impaired post-stroke rehab.Interpreters not trained to detect acquired neurogenic communication disorders (ACGs)
Needs Statement: We need a way to better detect and monitor ACDs in patients with LEPs to improve post-stroke quality of life
State of Art: Aphasia Rapid Test: 26 point scale assessment ;<3 minutes; debriefing before interpretting to some extent improves ACD detection;
Solution: Aphasia Rapid Test Translator tool: Questions asked in English translated to native language; patient's response translated back to English and scored by the provider; need Speech 2 text; neural machine translation;

Title: Glaucoma prevention in High Risk Hospitalized Patients
Observation: Glaucoma affects 2.7 millinon; leading cause of irreversable blindness; in critical care more chances of Glaucoma; Glaucoma: build up of pressure within the organ; damage the optixc nerve;
Needs Statement: A way to reduce glaucoma incidence in high-risk hospitalized patients in order to prevent irreversible vision loss
State of Art: Early treatment;
Solution: Improved screening and expedited treatment could reduce vision loss for undiagnosed glaucoma; Process change: protocol for thorough ocular exam in sedated patients; tonometry and fundoscopy; tonometry: interocular pressure measurement; fundal exam: directly looks at nerve.

Title: Enhancing Patient Education for Secondary Stroke Prevention
Observation: Stroke patient noncompliant with medicationl; second stroke highly likely after first few weeks of first stroke;
Needs Statement: Need to increase medication compliance in patients with recent stroke in order to reduce stroke readmission rates
State of Art: Patients are seen in stroke follow-up clinic within 6-8 weeks following stroke; this visit does not take place immediately; thus room for medication non compliance;Some solutions: supplementary test with images in discharge instructions; simplified information page; care transition intervention;
Solution: Pre-Exit Scanner: Tablet device at discharge will scan the patient's bracelet; the device would will pull up the patient's medication list; Quiz: Device will require patients to answer questions on medications; if patient is unsure, support team will call and clarify medication; Quiz modified for visual umpairment; sometimes quiz is for the family member; Quiz will ask identification of medication bottles

Title: Remote Neurological Exams
Keywords: telehealth; remote stroke exam; video capture
Observation: Patient's wife says patient is getting worse. Physical exam seems fine; a lttle slow and unbalanced in the right side. 16000 neurologists and 750k stroke patients a year, there is a shortage. 95% in urban and <1% in rural; Neuro exam consists of mental status, cranial nerve, motor, sensorty, reflex, which can be both subjective and objective measures. The reading can be different for different neurologists
Needs Statement: Need to provide a consistent objective measurement of traditionally subjective aspects of the physical exam in a remote setting
State of Art: Some existing solutions for objective parts of the neuro exam: PyGaze: for gaze tracking; GaitPy: video captue of gait;Blender: neuromuscular evaluation
Solution: Exam-o-phone: One stop shop of video capture with built-in open software capture that combines PyGaze, GaitPy, Blender and additional programs and compute NIH stroke scale. The neurologist at the hospital can then look through the results and triage the patients

Title: DigiPuncture
Observation: 30 yr old female with persistent headaches undergoing lumbar puncture to determine pressure in the cerebro-spinal fluid; It is a complex process that requires puncturing in the spine, accessing CSF and diverting it into a manometer to evaluate pressure; There is increased stress involving this process among new providers; This correlates with increased pain among patients; 360,000 LP annually performed; High BMI patients need radiology assisted LPs
Needs Statement: Need to simplify lumbar punctures so that providers can divert attention to their patient's comfort and make space for new bedside advancements
State of Art: IV infusion line with tape measure; Gwen gage tool; ultrasound guided lumbar puncture
Solution: Digi-Puncture: A manometer/pressure guage inbult within the needle. The needle has a Antechamber, which will be filled with the provider retracts the stylet. Pressure will be measured in the antechamber and then CSF will be drained from there by pullin the guidewire. Pressure gauage selection is crucial for this application.

Title: Better Mental Status Exam
Observation: Patients with TBI and stroke as they recover need to access how their cognition is changing/progressing/healing. Patients are usually subject to SLUMS exam. One particlualr patient's taste in video-games that require cognition changed
Needs Statement: Need a way to make a good assessment of higher order mental status of patients suffering from traumatic brain injuries and alzhiemers in order to provide better metrics of recovery
State of Art: keep a journal; Digital Neuropsychological assessment; video game for training of upper extremity function in children with cerebral palsy
Solution: Use of video games to see how patients were doing and journaling how they were progressing at cognitive skills. Brain games on smartphones like minesweepers, solitaire, soduku, brain teasers, trivia, call of duty played over the course of recovery.

Title: EEG Coreference Resolution
Observation: EMU patients are continuously monitored using EEG from days to week; Abnormal brain signals are of interest; but the abnormal signals could be due to multiple clinical factors not epilepsy related. These confounding factors must be clarified with the patient; these notes can also be found in the EHR, but need to be mined.
Needs Statement: Need a way to obtain relevant information of health conditions in EMU patients with abnormal brain signals to determine confounding factors that can affect the EEG signals
State of Art: keyword based search in Epic is avialable as opposed to conceptual; not possible to ask broad questions to retreive relevant information
Solution: Deep learning based semantic information retrieval; The major innovation is the development of large language model-based AI system which can perform zero-shot classification on medical records to extract pertinent information; When abnormal EEG signals are found, allow physicians to interact with the record in a QA format to surface relevant information.

Title: Water Monitor
Observation: Older adults who are susseptable to falls who live alone sometimes are unable to get up and thus are prone to stay put until someone finds them; Similar for dimentia patients as well; 1/4 of seniors fall every year; 1/5 of falls cause serious injury;2/3 of falls occur in the bathroom; Falls lead to dehydration->death. 60% of people with dimentia wonder. After 72 hrs of wandering if they are still not found, then their survival rate reduces to 20%
Needs Statement: Need a way to monitor the status such as falls in older adults who'd like to be autonomous so that caregivers and family can be quickly informed
State of Art: apple watch; life alert; GPS trackers; These are expensive and suffer from low adoption rates.
Solution: Non invasive monitoring that will not interfere with privacy or providing constant reminders of risk/disease; identify if patient has been away or immobile. Water monitor; If there is no water usage or continuous wate usage for 24 hrs then it will alert family members/ EMS

Title: DysarthrAI: Automated Dysarthria Detection
Observation: 44 yr male with left sided facial droop and weakness; poor dentition in neuro exam; NIH stroke scale 14; severe dysarthria; Dysarthria vs aphasia: Dysarthria is due to muscle weakness of the vocal apparatus, aphasia is speech difficulty due to damage of brain that controls language expression and comprehension; Aphasia is category 9 in NIH scale and dysarthria is scale 10; 8-60% of stroke patients have dysarthria; speech therapists is 200-250$ per hour
Needs Statement: There is a need for a better way to detect and track dysarthria in stroke patients in order to improve clinical outcomes.
State of Art: NIH stroke scale; patient asked to repeat certain common words; treated by a speech language pathologist; Multiple apps available: speech foot book for training. It does not provide real time feedback; can help with speech therapy
Solution: DysarthrAI: computer vision and facial motion tracking to provide accurate information on facial muscle movement; aids with diagnosis and tracking symptom resolution; A lot of existing tools on smartphones can be used.

Title: prolonging Independence in Alzheimer's disease patients
Observation: Cognitive decline with old age for patients with Alzhiemers may require them to move into an assistive living facility;Alzhiemers accounts for 60-80% of dimentia; 5-8 millinon in the US; Symptoms: difficulty remmbering newly learned info, memory loss, space time confusion, withdrawing from social activities
Needs Statement: There is a need to prolong Alzhiemer's disease patients' independence in order to improve their quality of life
State of Art: Several apps to track the patient: LIFE360 to track patients; smart stoves and smartlocks controled by wifi; research at the McKechnie Family LIFE homes
Solution: The Ultimate Incorporate current solutions and new ones into one single app; app tracks location from cell phone; medication from sensors from bottles; motion tracker to track patient mobility; smart stoves, locks and refridgerators; caregivers may be able to turn off/on devices from the app. Notifications will be sent to the patient's phone; Cons: patient may not be completely independent, dependent on wifi

Title: Comfortable Collars
Keywords: cervical collar; neck or spinal injury
Observation: Patient suffered accident; as he was recovering, he kept adjusting his cervical collar saying it was too tight; prolonged recovery time; Cervical collar used to immobilize the cervical spine and reduce risk of a secondary spinal cord injury; hard collars lead to pain, breathing restrictions; tissue ischemia
Needs Statement: There is a need for more personalized and effective cervical collar that allow patients to be more comfortable during their recovery period after a neck or spinal injury

Title: Predicting Coma Outcomes with EEG and Clinical Exams
Observation: When will comatose patients wake up? Comatose patients are subject to labs and imaging to check for potnetial causes; crude physicals are done on them; many patients are on EEG monitoring; the information is not used; Coma patientas are 0.4% of E;
Needs Statement: A way to predict when patients might emerge from coma in order to give clinicians and patients loved ones a more accurate prognosis
State of Art:
Coma management has two parts: Diagnostics and Monitoring; In Diagnostics we have Neuro exam, Head CT, Basic labs, MRI, EEG, Lu bar Puncture. 
In monitoring, we have neuro exam, electrolyte correction, Amantadine, swelling control, stimulants and Drug Antidote
Clinical measures can predict coma recovery with only 50% accuracy (Glasgow Coma Scale, Coma recovery scale-revised)
Solution:
Using continuous EEG monitoring augmenting normal clinical evaluations for predicting outcomes in comatose patients.
Come Etiology, continuous EEG monitoring and Dialy Neuro exam are inputs to multimodal ML model, which will then predict coma duraction and the functional status (will they walk, talk etc.)

Title: Proactive approach to identifying atrial fibrillation risk in cyptogenic embolic ischemic stroke patients
Keywords:
atrial fibrillation;
cryptogenic embolic ischemic stroke
Observation:
patient's brain imaging is consistent with ischemic stroke, but the etiology is unknown and thus the treatment plan is unknown (antiplatelet therapy or long-term anticoagulation)
1 in 4 patients stroke etiology unknown and thus are classified as cryptogenic. These patients undergo neuro imaging and cardiac assessment, which includes echocardiography. Once cardiac cause is identified then it is classified as a cardiogenic embolic stroke, which is around 15%
Needs Statement: Need a way to improve evaluation of atrial fibrillation risk in patients with acute ischemic stroke of cryptogenic origin in order to guide the most appropriate choice of treatment and secondary prevention strategies.
State of Art:
ECG monitoring for detection of Afib
pulse palpation, auscultation
Solution: Just like inducing epileptic seizures in ECG, patients will be subject to stimulus to induce atrial myopathy so that we can differentiate healthy patients from patients who are susseptible to atrial fibrilation

Title: Improving automated seizure detection
Observation:
Observation: High rate of automated false positives in the epilepsy monitoring unit
Natus system provides an alarm when a seizure occurs
EEG interpretation costs 120-470$/hour
If patient gets evaluated for epilepsy sooner there is a difference in mean cost of $4005
Needs Statement: Need a way for a faster, more seamless way to collect large amounts of ground-truth labelled EEG data for algorithm development
State of Art:
Successful deep learning approaches for automatic detection of seizures already exist
3D RCNN is able to detect preictal, ictal  and inter-ictal with an accuracy, specificity and sensitivity of around 90%
Why then is AI adoption lagging in healthcare?
Ans: data access limitations specifically related to difficulty gathering and centralizing data sets
Solution:
The native system already has windows to label ictal, preictal and postictal data. Proposed solution is on data collection for implementation
Consent-> HIPAA compliant database->training->deployment
Opt out policy for consent
Data sharing and federated learning

Title: Fixing Seizure Follow-Up
Observation:
Most patients who show up in the ED for seizures are admitted to in patient due to complications or comorbidities
Many other first-time seizure patients are discharged from the ED with plans for neurology follow up and work up on an outpatient:EEG and MRI
They are given an antiepileptic funnelled into the follow up list
The wait time to see a neurologist is greater than 3 months
Needs Statement: A need to reduce time taken for neurology consult follow up among patients with first-time seizures so as to reduce recurrent seizures and increase quality of care
State of Art:
Follow up of all epilepsy patients happens in the neuro clinic, which can cause delays
50% of seizure patients are lost to follow up
Solution:
Propose a follow-up seizure clinic that includes a telehealth option, 20 min visit, medications and emotional support
The call will act as a triage to determine need for inpatient visit, follow ups, psychiatry etc.
This clinic will be tied to the EMR

Title: PunctureSound
Observation:
Lumbar puncture requires puncturing and reaching the subarchnoid space containing the CSF fluid
Lumbar puncture can be done in the left lateral decubitus position, or sitting position, and in rare cases, the patient is sedated
Lumbar punctures could lead to complications such as headaches, cerebral herniation, infection etc.
400,000 LPs are performed annually in US, cost of LPs range from $400 to $4000
Needs Statement: Need a way to visualize and anatomically localize LP needle when performing lumbar puncture in pediatric and obese patients in order to increase the success of accessing the subarachnoid space.
State of Art:
Image guidance is used during difficult lumbar punctures: fluoroscopy and ultrasound
In fluoroscopy patients need to be rotated in the lld position to measure pressure
Solution:
Puncture sound: US probe with a LP needle canula and software to show the targeted path
Needle will be reloadable
Needle would be advanced along projected path through cannula

Title: NeurologyAndMe
Observation:
A large part of neurology is tracking progression
When a patient comes in, the previous normal state needs to be known.
Past history of the patient is difficult to obtain.
EMRs do not talk to each other. In the US 58% of errors were due to history, physical exam, test, referrals and communication
Needs Statement: Need an efficient and robust way to obtain longitudinal data for neurology patients in order to determine the right treatment and current status
State of Art:
EMR systems do not allow patients to own their data or communicate with other systems
Patients can also carry an emergency ID card
Family members carry your history of medical condition
Solution:
A QR code at the back of the driversrs lisence or state ID
Physicians would input data using NPI (10 digit identifiable code)
When scanned, a generalized picture of the brain would include areas that are demarcated
Technologies like cloud and blockchain can make this feasible
May lead to double documentation from the physician's standpoint

Title: How's my driving
Observation:
Patient with cognitive impairment 2-3 weeks poststroke
Is the patient ok to drive?
Provider needs to make the decision through mental and physical exam
Criteria for testing includes: visual fields, reaction time, verbal, reaction time (motor), dexterity, short term and long term memory, emotional stability
Needs Statement: Need a way to assess the ability of a patient to drive that is accepted by state law in neuro patients with cognitive decline
State of Art:
An OT test not coverable by insurance (300$)
A neurocognitive exam
An app preditcs when people are ready
Safety research is being conducted
Stakeholders: patients, government, insurace
Solution:
Combination of tests that aleady exists for all the different criteria for driving: visual fields, verbal and motor reaction, dexteity by pin testing.
Need to create a criteria for passing standard
Eventually reduce subjective decision making by medical professionals

Title: Deep Tendon Reflex Simulator
Observation:
Students with reflex hammer trying to perform deep tendon reflex (patellar reflex) on a patient
In the actual neurology setting, the students are unable to obtain the reflex
But the attending was able to elicit the reflex just fine
Deep tendon reflex: can be graded on a scale of 0-4
No practice
Needs Statement: Need an effective resource to practice physical exams such as eliciting reflexes for students and residents
State of Art:
Neuro simulator by Mayo clinic using VR but missing tactile elements
NeuroSim manikin that can be used to create emergency neuro conditions: pupilary response
Hsiao-Wecksler's lab simulator
Solution:
A Deep Tendon Reflex simulator that encompasses a link system connecting the foot and the lower leg to simulate the patellar reflex. 
The link will be controlled by an actuator and spring to simulate passive element as well
There are different modes that can be programmed: hypo and hyper relfex

Title: ETTS: A concentric double lumen endotracheal tube for aspiration mitigation
Observation:
Observation: An elderly woman wo underwent clot-busting thrombectomy died of aspiration. This was possibly because of her inability to protect her airways before intubation or occurred during intubation
Aspiration is the entry of organic secretions into the airways when patients cannot protect their airway. Post operative aspiration mortality is 27%
Needs Statement: There is a need to properly place the endotracheal tube with an inflated cuff in neuro-impaired patients in order to prevent aspiration during the intubation process
State of Art:
Rapid Sequence Intubation: seven steps for rapid placement of ETT in emergent situations.
Risk results from delayed placement and due to the intubation process itself
Despite RSI, incedence rate is 13.4%
Suctioning during intubation with a different catheter
Solution:
Rethinking ETT: Redesigning the endo tracheal tube to include a separate lumen for suctioning at the system's distal end. 
It would function similar to continuous suctioning during intubation but localizes that function in the trachea for maximum efficacy

Title: Reflexicuff
Observation: Neurologists are told to be cautious with other people's Deep tendon  reflex ratings
Needs Statement: Need an objective and standardized way to measure deep tendon reflexes for patients that transition from ED to in patient to reduce subjectivity and treatment time
State of Art:
NINDS scale for DTR 
Scale is from 0-4 with 2 being normal
Sometimes a + is added to bring out additional details
Some wearable sensors such as accelerometers, electrogoniometer MMG can be used
Solution:
Mechanomyography (MMG) cuff to detect muscle movements
Easy to don and off
Sensor quantify muscle response and output in the form of 0-4 scale
Cuff material must be flexible enough that it should elicit the reflex as usual
Data management and training is needed

Title: Threading the Electromyography Needle: Improving its Diagnostic Accuracy with imaging and machine learning
Observation:
Neuromuscular diseases such as carpal tunnel syndrome, Guillain-Barre syndrome and ALS require accurate EMG 
Location of the probe extremely important for EMG; slight changes in probe position causes large changes 
Patinets untreated within 1 yr increases for 70-90%
EMG centers are scares in rural areas
Needs Statement: Need to incorporate accurate anatomical features to guide the placement of EMG probe in patients with neuromuscular diseases so as to obtain an accurate EMG reading
State of Art:
Ultrasound guided EMG to identify anatomical structures
Ultrasound guided 3D reconstruction
Both require training
Solution:
Improve accuracy of EMG with minimal training
Ultrasound guided EMG using acoustic/Young's modulus of the signals 
Machine learning creates a color coded maps for the EMG technicians 
Data sets to train this model, need to know the Young's modulus

Title: Adaptive Brace for MS: Straight ArMS
Observation:
Spasticity is an abnormal tightening of muscles due to extended contraction
An MS patient could not extend her leg and could not transfer into the car
1 million in US have MS, and 60-80% have spasticity
Spasticity can lead to contractures and pressure ulcers
Needs Statement: Need an external mechanism to aid in lifting of the leg for MS patients that experience spasticity so that they can move with independence
State of Art:
Physical therapy, magnetic stimulation, Baclofen, botulinum toxin A
Outpatient exercise, robotic gait training, 
Active exoskeletons
Solution:
Passive Assistive bracing
Lightweight, cheaper, no battery
Multitasking may be challenging
Require upper body strength to straighten the leg
Car transfer adaptation may be added

Title: Reimagining imaging techniques for lumbar punctures
Observation:
Several patients required multiple attempts at the lumpar puncture
Patient's body habitus is occasionally not compatible with imaging equipment 
spinal curvature and increased body habitus requires the physician to use longer needles that decrease accuracy
Overall success rate is still 80%
Needs Statement: The need to accurately detect the spine curvature anatomy in patients with abnormal spine curvature to increase the accuracy of lumbar puncture
State of Art:
"Radioactive sources of imaging: fluoroscopy
Non radioactive sources: Ultrasound"
Solution:
Propose an ultrasound probe that utilizes two different wave emitting areas to generate a 3D image
Current cross sectional image of US requires formal training to use
Therefore, two probes can create 2 cross sections that intersect at a given point, such as the vertebrae, and could therefore create a 3D image of the interested anatomy.
Idea: combining two probes with a bendable component between them which can allow for customization of the length for each patient
Very little triaining is needed

Title: Brain Buddy
Observation:
ED patient gave a different NIH stroke scale stroke different from the neurology consult
This is an issue in communicating consult and impacts management and urgency
Most discrepency is in gaze, visual fields, ataxia, sensory and extinction areas
Needs Statement: A way to increase consistency in the NIH stroke scale scores provided by the ED physicians and the neurologists in patients who are transferred from ED to inpatient to more accurately assess severity and location of the stroke
State of Art:
There are other scales including CPSS, FAST, LAPSS and ROSIER
NIHSS is the gold standard
There is MDCalc app that calculates the NIHSS given the condition

Brain buddy: the physicians will wear an AR headset when assessing the stroke patient, and record the video
Physician zooms into critical areas 
Part of the data is used to train an expert labeled machine learning, and the other in testing and validation
Trained data will be able to guide intra-user and inter-user consistency

Title: Sleep-Stress inSight
Observation:
Patients came in with relapse in migraines
This could have been due to a lack of sleep and excessive stress
While patients are educated on the effect of seizures and headaches
Needs Statement: A way to monitor daily stress levels and sleep factors for patients with migraine and seizures so as to guage the risk for relapse
State of Art:
There are many tools to track sleep quality and stress metrics :OURA ring and Apple watch
none of them correlate these with their condition
Other wearables exist for this as well

Sleep-Stress inSight App would be a downloadable app where the patinet enters their sleep hours, sleep quality, stress levels, whether they took their medications and if they had a relapse of the condition

Recommendations for lifestyle change
Will provide physicians with continuous information on the data

Title: Brain-Check
Observation:
Neurological exam is hard to memorize. Relying on memory could miss limited positive findings in neuropathologies, particularly stroke.
There needs to be a convenient, comprehensive, reproducable manner of completing the neurological exam
Stroke malpractive suits settle for an average of $1.8 mil
Fully automated solutions are hard
Needs Statement: A way to keep track of the different steps of the neurological exam for neurologists so as to prevent return visits and miss key aspects for stroke diagnostics
State of Art: A paper and computer-based chart with all the neuro exam steps.
Solution:
Brain Check: App with templates of neuro exam; some steps that are less common are greyed out
Text-to-Speech reminder of the steps will be available
First the physican manually selects a template- doctor conducts test-doctor states negative or positive followed by a description- the app may suggest additional tests based on the doctor's results
Challenge to convince the doctors to use it

Title: Precise Plus
Observation:
34 yr old female in ICU with loss of vision in the left eye. Neuro exams in ICU are high paced. Muscular strength had to be reproduced with another physician
Muscle strength testing is an important component of the physical exam that can reveal information about neurologic deficits. 
It is used to evaluate weakness and can be effective in differentiating true weakness from imbalance or poor endurance.
Limitations of the Grading Scale
Muscle being tested may have no clinical relevance
There may be individual variation in reporting
Only assesses muscles which are contracting in a concentric manner
The scale may not be applicable in all patients
Needs Statement: A way to assess muscular function in a reproducable fashion in the ICU in order to determine neurological deficit
State of Art:
Patients are asked to push and pull with legs bent, resist doctor's force etc. 
Left and right leg comparison may detect a small change, which could signal some neuro deficit
Solution:
A gym equipment based solution that can calculate change in force over time. 
A plate with a spring for lower and upper extremities to push 
This methodology involve integration of various quantitative parameters to directly and robustly evaluate characteristics of an individual muscle strength during a neuro exam

Title: Strike-A-Stroke
Observation:
An elderly patient with stroke shows up and his risk factors include: chain smoking, noncompliance to medication, hypertension and hyperlipidemia, age and uncontrolled diabetes
These are modifiable risk factors, but too late for patients to change
In 2020, 1 in 6 deaths from cardiovascular disease was due to stroke
795k stroke deaths per year, with costs around 53 billion dollars per year 
Consequences of poor health choices are not imminent
Most patients progress towards stroke slow enough that dont notice it but fast enough to hurt them
Non adherence to medication can account for 50% of treatment failures and 125k death
Needs Statement: A need to present customizable education material to stroke patients with modifiable risk factors so as to increase medication compliance and promote healthier lifestyle
State of Art:
Barriers to medication adherence is due to: fear towards drugs, diseases where poor control does not yet present symptoms
Facilitators to better medication adherence according to the general practitioners is : focus on health coutcomes of self-management and drug therapies
Support for patients to better understand their diseases and its management
2013 ACC/AHA Guideline on the assessment of cardiovascular risk gives a 10 year prediction of heart disease or stroke
Solution:
Bring the future, far away vision of reality closer to the patient in an easily comprehensible manner through visual learning, data-based approach.
An app with input of the patient's parameters (age, history) etc. and a smiley face prediction for the future
The patient will be able to track the progress (much like growth charts)

Title: PestiSafe – Pesticide Exposure Prevention
Observation:
Jul 19, 2016, 60 corn detasslers experienced organophosphate poisoning through pesticide exposure in McLean County, IL working in corn fields
Workers were unaware that the corn fields they were detasseling had been treated with pesticides the night before
The detasselers started experiencing dermatitis, nausea/vomiting, blurry vision, headache, dizziness, and even as severe as respiratory failure
Similar stories, whether through crop dusters direct spraying on farmers, spray drift land on workers, or contact with pesticide residues, occur every year (~100 reported cases in IL each year, 3000 nationally)
Needs Statement: A way to track and prevent pesticide exposure in farmworkers
State of Art:
Rural settings typically are under-resourced for medical care
Patient triage is even more important to determine which patients can be given a seat on the ambulance for higher-acuity care
Decontamination stations need to be set up rapidly, with sufficient PPE needed for emergency responders to aid chemically-exposed patients
Patient belongings must be tossed or kept away due to being contaminated
Busses, ambulances, hospital bed, etc must be decontaminated afterwards as well
Current Safety measures: Signs indicating unsafe fields
Crop dusters circle fields, checking for humans (wearing bright orange hats) prior to pesticide spray
Makeshift shower tents and decontamination stations for acute pesticide exposure events
Disposable coveralls to wear after contact with pesticides, as it is required to strip off and dispose of contaminated clothes
Self-reports of pesticide exposure to CDC, EPA, etc.
Solution:
Farmers can mark fields they are actively working in with an easily transportable, ultra-light pole with a flag/banner attached
The flag will allow crop duster airplane pilots to more easily identify fields to avoid
Fluorescent orange color (same as safety vests) to enable visibility from afar by crop duster airplane pilots
Flag can also be an indicator of wind direction, in combination with wind speed, can help the pilot determine amount of pesticide spray drift
Soil pesticide biosensors – map of safe fields can be developed from this information
Wearable pesticide biosensors
convert soil pesticide biosensors to a wearable format
Enable farmers to understand their quantitative level of pesticide exposure
Aid in decision making to stop working when pesticide exposure is excessive
Aid in decision to seek further medical care when pesticide exposure is excessive before acute/chronic symptoms manifest

Title: TeleFamily
Observation:
Elderly patient with Alzheimers developed delirium in the hospital.
Patient was confused and tried to pull IV and was going to leave
It is frequently difficult for family members to be involved in a loved one’s hospital stay, yet family members are the preferred providers in the treatment of delirium
A recent meta-analysis found delirium’s prevalence to be 23% of all hospital stays [3]
A recent meta-analysis found delirium’s prevalence to be 23% of all hospital stays
Needs Statement: A way to reorient patients with the involvement of their family in older patients with Alheimers in order to prevent the onset of delirium
State of Art: There has been studies showing that specialized units who made attempts to make the space as least “hospital-like” as possible, including  less background noise and less hospital equipment in the rooms can decrease delirium
Solution:
Solution: an in-room screen where family members can send videos that would help re-orient the patient and could be controlled primarily by family members 
The screen could either be playing pre-recorded videos, or as family members have time they could hop onto “facetime” and talk with the patient and help re-orient them 
The screen would be controlled by family members and could be monitored by a nurse 
Nurse could communicate to family members that they are starting to show signs of delirium/need re-orientation (as is done now) 
Family members could record themselves and send it to the screen with re-orienting statements

Title: Walk it out: Aerobic Exercise and Fostering Community in Patients with Dementia
